Novel Baswedan Berencana Keluar dari KPK, Jika...
02 Nov 2019, 05:15 by M Rosseno Aji, Endri Kurniawati
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Penyidik senior Komisi Pemberantasan Korupsi Novel Baswedan berencana keluar dari lembaga antirasuah tempatnya bekerja. Ia akan keluar dari KPK bila bisa memastikan pemerintah sudah tidak ingin ada pemberantasan korupsi.
"Saya hampir bisa memastikan pemerintah tidak berkeinginan memberantas korupsi. Kalau itu bisa saya pastikan, saya keluar dari KPK," kata Novel saat dihubungi, Sabtu, 2 November 2019.
Novel beranggapan pemerintah sudah tidak ingin ada pemberantasan korupsi. Karena itu, menurut dia, akan aneh bila KPK getol memberantas korupsi, namun pemerintah enggan melakukannya. "Kan lucu kalau pemerintah tidak ingin memberantas korupsi, terus kita berjuang memberantas korupsi untuk apa?"
Sikap pemerintahan Presiden Joko Widodo yang paling membuat kecewa mantan perwira Polri ini ialah revisi UU KPK. Dia mengatakan perubahan dalam UU itu telah melemahkan komisi antikorupsi. "UU itu mematikan KPK."
Novel mengatakan sikap Jokowi yang tidak kunjung menerbitkan Peraturan Pemerintah Pengganti UU KPK atau Perpu KPK membuatnya semakin yakin bahwa pemerintah tidak berpihak pada pemberantasan korupsi.
Menurut mantan perwira Polri ini upaya pelemahan KPK saat ini terjadi dengan sistematis. Tidak hanya melalui revisi UU KPK, namun media sosial juga diramaikan oleh ulah buzzer yang menyerang pegawai KPK secara personal dan membuat persepsi seolah revisi UU KPK dilakukan dengan tujuan baik. "Itu saya pikir bukan terjadi secara natural," kata dia.
Novel adalah lulusan akademi Polri tahun 1998. Pada 2007, mabes Polri menugaskan pria kelahiran Semarang, 42 tahun silam ini ke KPK. Novel memilih meninggalkan Korps Bhayangkara dan menjadi penyidik tetap KPK sejak 2014. Sejumlah kasus besar yang pernah ia tangani di antaranya, kasus korupsi mantan Bendahara Umum Partai Demokrat M. Nazaruddin dan kasus suap mantan Ketua Mahkamah Konstitusi Akil Mochtar.
Pada 2017, dua orang tak dikenal menyiram wajah Novel dengan air keras. Kejadian ini menyebabkan mata Novel Baswedan nyaris buta. Dua tahun berlalu, polisi gagal mengungkap pelaku penyerangan.
text:
Novel Baswedan Plans to Get Out of the KPK, If ...
02 Nov 2019, 05:15 by M Rosseno Aji, Endri Kurniawati
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - A senior investigator at the Corruption Eradication Commission, Baswedan, plans to leave the interfaith institution where he works. He will leave the KPK if he can ensure the government does not want to eradicate corruption.
"I can almost be sure that the government does not wish to eradicate corruption. If I can confirm it, I will quit the KPK," Novel said when contacted on Saturday, November 2, 2019.
The novel assumes the government does not want to eradicate corruption. Therefore, according to him, it would be strange if the KPK was keen to eradicate corruption, but the government was reluctant to do so. "Isn't it funny if the government does not want to eradicate corruption, then what are we fighting to eradicate corruption for?"
The attitude of President Joko Widodo's government that most disappointed the former Polri officer was the revision of the KPK Law. He said changes in the law had weakened the anticorruption commission. "The law killed the KPK."
Novel said that Jokowi's attitude of not issuing Government Regulations in lieu of the KPK Law or KPK Perpu made him even more convinced that the government was not in favor of fighting corruption.
According to this former Polri officer, efforts to weaken the KPK currently occur systematically. Not only through the revision of the KPK Law, but social media was also enlivened by buzzers who personally attacked KPK employees and made a perception as if the revision of the KPK Law was carried out with good intentions. "That I think is not happening naturally," he said.
Novel is a graduate of the National Police Academy in 1998. In 2007, the National Police Headquarters assigned the man born in Semarang, 42 years ago to the KPK. Novel chose to leave the Bhayangkara Corps and become a permanent investigator of the Corruption Eradication Commission since 2014. A number of large cases he has handled include, the corruption case of former Democratic Party Treasurer M. Nazaruddin and the bribery case of former Constitutional Court Chief Akil Mochtar.
In 2017, two unknown people splashed Novel's face with hard water. This incident caused the eyes of Novel Baswedan almost blind. Two years later, the police failed to reveal the perpetrators of the attack.
